metadata.case_name: Appellant (Returned Candidate from Farber Constituency) v. First Respondent

facts.text: General Elections held in 1954 to the Legislative Assembly of the Patiala and East Punjab States Union from the Farber Constituency.
Appellant was one of the candidates, secured the largest number of votes, and was declared duly elected.
Result notified in the Official Gazette on February 27, 1954.
Return of election expenses published in Official Gazette on May 2, 1954.

First respondent filed election petition under s. 81 of Representation of the People Act, 1951 on May 18, 1954, praying that appellant's election be declared void on grounds of corrupt and illegal practices by appellant and agents.
Rule 119(a) prescribes petition against returned candidate to be presented not later than 14 days from publication of return of election expenses under Rule 113.
Last date for filing petition was May 16, 1954, which was a Sunday, and May 17, 1954 was a public holiday.
Petition presented on May 18, 1954; paragraph 6 stated offices closed on 16th and 17th, so within limitation.
Election Commission order: petition filed on 18-5-1954, but for holidays on 16-5-1954 and 17-5-1954 would be time-barred; admit.
Appellant filed written statement denying allegations and contending petition not presented within time under Rule 119(a).
Election Tribunal overruled time-bar plea applying s.10 General Clauses Act via Rule 26 of Election Rules.

Tribunal held on merits that appellant employed 25 persons in addition to those allowed under Rule 118 and Schedule VI for payment in connection with election, committing corrupt practice under s.123(7).
Tribunal declared election void under s.100(2)(b) and observed disqualification under ss.140(1)(a) and 140(2).
Appellant is quondam ruler of Faridkot, retained large staff of subordinates post-merger in Pepsu.
First respondent charged 54 staff members employed for election purposes, violating Rule 118.

Tribunal finding: 25 named persons took part in election campaign apart from polling agent duties; all paid employees of appellant exceeding statutory number under Rule 118; not specially engaged for election but still guilty of corrupt practice.
No evidence of additional allowances paid to 25 employees; emoluments not chargeable to election account as long-term service.
Evidence by first respondent largely that appellant's men did election work in morning or evening, out of office hours.

legal_issues.text: Whether the election petition was presented within the time prescribed by Rule 119(a), given filing on May 18, 1954 after holidays on May 16-17.
Whether there was contravention of Rule 118 by employment of 25 staff members for payment in connection with the election.

petitioner_arguments.text: Election petition not presented within time under Rule 119(a) as 'not later than fourteen days' differs from 'within a prescribed period'; s.10 General Clauses Act inapplicable; petition liable to dismissal under s.90(4).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 119(a); s.10 General Clauses Act; contrasted with Rule 123; proviso to s.37 RPA

petitioner_arguments.text: No contravention of Rule 118 as employees were long-term staff not specially/ad hoc engaged for election; salary not for election work; casual work in addition to normal duties.

respondent_arguments.text: Petition within time as offices closed on last days; s.10 General Clauses Act applies.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.10 General Clauses Act; Rule 26 Election Rules

respondent_arguments.text: Rule 118 violated as 25 paid employees of appellant worked in election campaign exceeding allowed numbers; sufficient that employed by candidate and paid, no need for special engagement.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 118; s.123(7) RPA; observations in Hartlepools Case, Amritsar Case, Farrukhabad Case

court_reasoning.text: s.10 General Clauses Act applies to Rule 119(a) as 'not later than fourteen days' means same as 'within fourteen days'; period prescribed expires on holiday, act done next open day is in time; Rule heading confirms; proviso s.37 not excluding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petition filed May 18 entitled to protection of s.10; in time.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 118 requires employment in connection with election for payment; not special engagement needed, but work must be under contract of employment for election, not casual/additional to normal duties; if switched to whole/substantially whole-time election work, then applies; salary then election payment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No finding that 25 staff relieved of normal work and put on election work; evidence shows out-of-hours work, additional to duties.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents like Hartlepools distinguish casual vs. dedicated election employment; burden on respondent not discharged.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No remand needed as evidence insufficient.

holdings.text: Election petition presented in due time under Rule 119(a) read with s.10 General Clauses Act.
No contravention of Rule 118 absent finding of staff put on election work superseding normal duties.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote
precedents_cited.relevance: Judicial recognition of Faridkot as independent State during British regime.
Distinction in election expenses/salary for staff doing election work; casual vs. dedicated employment.
Remarks on staff employment in elections.
Wages for staff put on election work should be shown; limited authority.
Salaries for exclusive election work periods to be included.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs election petitions, corrupt practices, disqualification, time limits.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Extension of time if last day holiday; applicable via Rule 26.

statutes_cited.name: Conduct of Elections Rules (Election Rules)
statutes_cited.relevance: Time for filing petitions; limit on paid employees; application of General Clauses Act.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of Election Tribunal set aside; election petition dismissed as no contravention of Rule 118 proved.

key_quotes.text: "Broadly stated, the object of the section is to enable a person to do what he could have done on a holiday, on the next working day."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose and application of s.10 General Clauses Act to limitation issue.

key_quotes.text: "Rule 118 does not require that the person engaged by a candidate to work in the election should have been specially employed for the purpose of the election. It is sufficient... that person is employed in connection with the election."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation of Rule 118 on employment for election.

key_quotes.text: "But if, on the other hand, he takes them out of their normal work and puts them on whole-time or substantially whole-time work in connection with the election, that would amount to converting their general employment into one in connection with the election."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes casual additional work from employment triggering Rule 118.
